We can model the interaction of an oscilloscope with the device under test (DUT) with the following circuit.
A typical modern oscilloscope has an input resistance of \(R_s = $RSM\)M\(\Omega\) and an input capacitance of \(12 < C_s < 25\)pF. Assume that the input capacitance of our oscilloscope \(C_s = $CSp\)pF.
The oscilloscope is connected to the circuit with a 10X probe with resistance of \(R_p = $RPM\)M\(\Omega\). The probe incorporates a variable capacitor, adjustable with a special tool, that is in parallel with the resistance in the probe. The purpose of this capacitor is to compensate for the capacitance of the input circuit of the oscilloscope.
The device under test is modeled as a voltage source with voltage \(v_M\).
If the frequency of the source being measured is very low or a DC value, for example \(v_M = $VM\)V, what is the value of the voltage \(v_S\), in Volts, that the oscilloscope sees?
The oscilloscope is used to measure and display waveforms at many frequencies. Suppose that \(v_M = $Vin1 \cos({2 \pi\ $fM1\times10^6\ t})\ \)V. What is the value, in picoFarads, that \(C_p\) should be set to so that \(V_s = $VS1\)V? Hint: think about ratios of impedances.
